text:
Coursework highlights the tools and theory I use for data science, with an emphasis on modeling, decision-making, and scalable computation.









Applied machine learning for real-world decision-making. Focuses on model evaluation under uncertainty, causal inference methods, and practical deployment of ML systems for high-impact decisions.

Python Applied ML Causal Inference











Comprehensive regression theory from OLS and Gauss-Markov theorem to GLMs and generalized estimating equations. Covers heteroskedasticity, cluster-robust inference, model selection, shrinkage methods (Ridge/LASSO), and extensions to categorical and count outcomes.

Python Regression GLMs











Probabilistic machine learning theory covering empirical risk minimization, complexity bounds, and uniform laws. Emphasizes model evaluation via cross-validation, regularization schemes, classification with proxy losses, and connections between linear models and sophisticated ML methods.

Python Deep Learning Optimization











Theoretical foundations and applications of ML from problem formulation to model deployment. Covers unsupervised learning (k-means, PCA), regression and classification, deep learning architectures (CNNs, RNNs, transformers), and generative models (LLMs, GANs). Includes PyTorch implementation and backpropagation.

Python ML Theory Algorithms











Bayesian inference framework including prior elicitation, conjugate analysis, and hierarchical modeling. Focuses on MCMC methods (Gibbs sampling, Metropolis-Hastings), modern computational techniques (HMC, variational inference), and applications to complex statistical models.

Python MCMC Hierarchical Models
















Measure-theoretic probability, convergence concepts, laws of large numbers, central limit theorems, and foundational theory for statistical inference.

Theory Measure Theory Convergence











Statistical inference theory including sufficiency, exponential families, hypothesis testing, asymptotic theory, and decision theory foundations.

Theory Inference Asymptotics











Statistical computing and data science using Python. Covers UNIX/bash scripting, version control, data manipulation, text processing, object-oriented programming, parallel processing, databases and big data, computer arithmetic, simulation and Monte Carlo methods, numerical linear algebra, and optimization.

Python UNIX/Bash Parallel Computing Numerical Methods

NoteThe Story at a Glance



In 2020, our team built an AI system to forecast water demand for my hometown of Monterrey, Mexico. We won 2nd place globally at the Atos IT Challenge, the first Mexican team ever to achieve this distinction in the competition‚Äôs 10-year history.
Two years later, our predictions came true. Monterrey plunged into a severe water crisis, forcing 5 million residents to survive on minimal daily water allocations for nearly two years.

title: Digital Water Forecast
text:
Atos IT Challenge 2020 ‚Äî 2nd Place (First Mexican team in the competition‚Äôs history)
Digital Water is a cooperative-AI prototype built to help city utilities forecast water demand and available capacity. Using official data from Agua y Drenaje de Monterrey (SADM), we modeled daily demand and dam capacity to surface early warning signals for shortages.

title: Digital Water Forecast
text:
Context
This project focused on Monterrey, Mexico, my hometown. At the time, we did not realize the city was on the verge of a major water crisis that unfolded two years later. The work highlighted how proactive forecasting can shift utilities from reactive operations to preventative planning.

title: Digital Water Forecast
text:
Approach
We built an end-to-end Python workflow that: 1. Cleaned and aligned multi-source time-series data (consumption + dam capacity). 2. Trained two LSTM models to forecast daily demand and daily capacity. 3. Produced outputs that estimated ‚Äúdays-to-threshold‚Äù for safe levels. 4. Presented results via a web dashboard (hosted on Heroku at the time).

title: Digital Water: Predicting a Crisis Before It Happened
section: What If You Could See a Crisis Coming?
text:
What If You Could See a Crisis Coming?
Between November 2019 and July 2020, my team developed Digital Water, a machine learning platform to forecast water demand and capacity at the city level. Working with real data from Monterrey‚Äôs official water utility (SADM), we built LSTM neural networks that could predict daily water consumption and available dam capacity.
At the time, we were focused on winning an international competition. We didn‚Äôt realize we were documenting the early warning signs of a catastrophe.

title: Digital Water: Predicting a Crisis Before It Happened
text:
The Challenge
Monterrey is Mexico‚Äôs third-largest metro area and a major industrial hub. The city‚Äôs water system serves over 5 million people, drawing from a network of dams and underground sources. But water scarcity was becoming more frequent, and utilities were operating reactively, responding to shortages rather than preventing them.
Our goal: Build a forecasting system that could shift water management from reactive to preventative, giving utilities early warning signals before reaching critical thresholds.

title: Digital Water: Predicting a Crisis Before It Happened
text:
Our Solution
We developed an end-to-end machine learning pipeline:

Data Engineering

Collected and cleaned multi-source time-series data from SADM
Aligned daily consumption records with dam capacity measurements
Created comprehensive field dictionaries and documentation



Predictive Models

Trained two LSTM neural networks (one for demand, one for capacity)
Forecasted daily water demand and available capacity
Calculated ‚Äúdays-to-threshold‚Äù estimates for safe operating levels
Implemented in Python using TensorFlow



Deployment

Built an interactive web dashboard (hosted on Heroku)
Created Google Colab notebooks for accessibility and reproducibility
Produced technical documentation and presentation materials







TipKey Technologies



Python ‚Ä¢ TensorFlow ‚Ä¢ LSTM Networks ‚Ä¢ Time Series Forecasting ‚Ä¢ Google Colab ‚Ä¢ Heroku

title: Digital Water: Predicting a Crisis Before It Happened
text:
What Happened Next: The Crisis
In 2022, everything our models predicted came to pass.
Monterrey experienced a devastating water crisis that lasted nearly two years. The city‚Äôs 5 million residents were reduced to minimal daily water allocations. Neighborhoods received water only a few hours per week. Businesses struggled. The crisis validated our forecasting approach‚Äîbut also showed the human cost of delayed action.






WarningTimeline



2019-2020: Built forecasting models with SADM data
July 2020: Won 2nd place at Atos IT Challenge
2022: Water crisis begins‚Äîpredictions validated
2022-2024: Nearly two years of severe rationing for 5M residents
2024: Crisis subsides


The crisis highlighted how proactive forecasting can shift utilities from reactive operations to preventative planning‚Äîand why such systems need to be deployed, not just built.

title: Digital Water: Predicting a Crisis Before It Happened
text:
Technical Details
For those interested in the implementation:

Models: Two LSTM neural networks (demand + capacity forecasting)
Data: Official records from Agua y Drenaje de Monterrey (SADM)
Features: Multi-variate time series including consumption patterns, dam levels, and seasonal factors
Outputs: Daily forecasts + ‚Äúdays-to-threshold‚Äù risk estimates
Code: Open-source notebooks in Google Colab
Documentation: Complete technical report and research summaries

title: Digital Water: Predicting a Crisis Before It Happened
text:
Reflection
This project was completed in 2020, and the notebooks remain as-is in the repository. Looking back (5 years later) with more experience in ML, I would redesign the data pipeline, modeling aproach, stability and predictability of the model and scalability. But the core lesson remains: predictive models only create impact when they‚Äôre deployed and acted upon.
The crisis our system forecasted was preventable. The data was there. The models worked. What was missing was the infrastructure and institutional will to act on early warnings.

Built between November 2019 and July 2020 as part of the Atos IT Challenge.
